text:
FLOWER

Angiosperms, or flowering seed plants, form seeds in ovaries. As the seeds develop, the ovaries may develop into fruits. Flowers attract pollinators, and fruits encourage animals to disperse the seeds. 

Parts of a Flower

A flower consists of male and female reproductive structures. The main parts of a flower are; stamen, pistil, petals, and sepals.

Stamen

The stamen is the male reproductive structure of a flower. It consists of a stalk-like filament that ends in an anther. The anther contains pollen sacs, in which meiosis occurs and pollen grains form. The filament raises the anther up high so its pollen will be more likely to blow in the wind or be picked up by an animal pollinator. All the stamen together forms the androecium. 

Pistil/carpel

The pistil is the female reproductive structure of a flower. It consists of a stigma, style, and ovary. The stigma is raised and sticky to help it catch pollen. The style supports the stigma and connects it to the ovary, which contains the egg. Petals attract pollinators to the flower.

Petals

Petals are often brightly colored so pollinators will notice them. Sepals protect the developing flower while it is still a bud. Sepals are usually green, which camouflages the bud from possible consumers. The petals of flower pollinated by wind may be absent or reduced but they are very colourful in insect pollinated flower.

Complete Flower

All four kinds of floral organs, sepals, petals, stamens and carpels are present in so-called complete flowers, but some flowers, which are said to be incomplete, lack one or more of them.

Double fertilization is a special type of fertilization which occurs only in angiospermic plants. During this process a sperm fuses with the ovum to form oospore. The other sperm fuses with secondary nucleus to form triploid endosperm nucleus. 

After fertilization, the ovule matures into a seed, which, as in pine, consists of seed coat stored food, and embryo. However, the angiosperm seed differs from that of pine in being enveloped by the ovary. It is the ovary that develops into the fruit, usually enlarging greatly in the process. Sometimes other structures associated with the ovary, such as the receptacle, are also incorporated into the fruit.

NB: Bisexual or perfect flowers have both male (androecium) and female (gynoecium) reproductive structures, including stamens and an ovary. 

Perfect flowers can pollinate itself and does not need wind, insects or other means to transfer its pollen. Examples of crops with perfect flowers include apples, cherries and legumes.

Flowers that contain both androecium and gynoecium are called hermaphroditic.

 

NB: Bisexual or perfect flowers have both male (androecium) and female (gynoecium) reproductive structures, including stamens and an ovary. 

Perfect flowers can pollinate itself and does not need wind, insects or other means to transfer its pollen. Examples of crops with perfect flowers include apples, cherries and legumes.

Flowers that contain both androecium and gynoecium are called hermaphroditic.

 

UNN PUTME Example

1. A flower that has both stamens and pistil is said to be 

A. staminate B. pistillate C. perfect D. imperfect 

(C. A perfect flower is one that contains both the male and female parts and may be described as “bisexual" or “hermaphroditic”, 2017/2018, no 2)

 

2. In the process of pollination of a flowering plant, the pollen grain must touch this structure to start off.

A. petals B. calyx C. ovary D. stigma

(D. stigma, Pollination in flowering plant involves the pollen grain male reproductive touching the stigma female reproductive structure, 2005/2006, no 3).

 

3. A pollen grain produces two male gametes; one is used to form the zygote while the other forms the endosperm by fusing with

A. other pollens B. embryo sac C. polar nuclei D. haploid spore

(C. In Double Fertilization in plants embryo, the first male gamete fertilizes the egg to formzygote while the other male gamete fuses with another cell, the polar nuclei which developes into endosperm (food storing tissue, 2005/2006, no 12)

 

4. A flower that has both stamen and pistil is said to be

A. perfect B. imperfect C. pistillate D. staminate

(A. Bisexual or perfect flowers have both male (androecium) and female (gynoecium) reproductive structures, including stamens and an ovary. Flowers that contain both androecium and gynoecium are called hermaphroditic)

 

5. The tomato fruit is a very good example of

A. an aggregate fruit B. a drupe C. a berry D. a multiple fruit

(A berry is a fruit without a stone (like the pit you find in peaches and plums) produced from a single flower and containing a single ovary. Tomatoes fit this definition. This however, is from a strict biological perspective. If you go by this definition, grapes and bananas and even watermelons are considered berries).

 

6. The ovary of a flower develops and becomes a

A. seed B. fruit C. stalk D. petal

(B. Ovary, in botany, enlarged basal portion of the pistil, the female organ of a flower. The ovary contains ovules, which develop into seeds upon fertilization2012/2013 II, no 2)
